prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this question. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation involves a husband setting up his home office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife, who is also working from home and handling most household chores and kids. 

First, I need to understand both sides. The husband chose the bedroom for his office because he likes the view better, despite the basement being available and offering more silence. The wife is upset because she can't use the top floor, including the bathroom, and her ability to manage work and household tasks is hindered. She suggested the basement, which the husband rejected.

The main issue here is about reasonable accommodation and mutual consideration. The husband's job is mostly conference calls, so he needs a quiet space, which he's choosing not to use the available basement for. The wife, on the other hand, is dealing with the household, which is disrupted by his choice. 

I should consider if the wife is being unreasonable by not keeping the bedroom undisturbed. But the husband's choice to set up in the bedroom is the root cause. The wife is trying to manage her own responsibilities, which are being impacted. The husband's preference for the view over practicality might make him the one causing the problem. 

Also, the wife is taking on most of the household chores and childcare, which is a common dynamic in many households, though not necessarily fair. The fact that there's a basement available that would solve the issue but the husband refuses because of the view is a key point. The wife's refusal to guarantee silence is a response to his choice, so she's not at fault. 

Therefore, the wife (author) is not in the wrong. The answer should be B.
